quotes.topic_title: Leadership: being loved vs being liked
quotes.text: I do not believe in being liked. I believe in being loved, right? And that's a very, very different thing.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: Reframes leadership away from popularity toward deeper care that can support tougher, more effective management decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Leadership: being loved vs being liked
quotes.text: love is the choice to extend yourself for the spiritual growth of oneself or another, right?
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: Offers a practical definition of “love” as a leadership standard: investing effort to help someone grow.

quotes.topic_title: Leadership: being loved vs being liked
quotes.text: And when you are extending yourself, you're not nice. It's not always nice or like, it sometimes is having hard conversations.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: Gives actionable guidance that caring leadership includes directness and difficult feedback, not just pleasant interactions.

quotes.topic_title: Leadership: being loved vs being liked
quotes.text: So when the feedback is coming like raw, they know that it's in their best interest because I've shown enough times that I genuinely care about the person behind the role.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: Explains the trust mechanism that makes candid feedback land: repeated demonstrations of care for the human, not just the job.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Ebi shares the most tactical advice I've ever heard on how to develop a vision for your product, along with a bunch of very concrete ways to communicate your vision to your teammates and to executives.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Sets up the episode’s core promise: practical methods for creating and communicating product vision across levels.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: One of the most effective ways to create a big leap in your career and something that worked really well for me a few years ago is to create a personal board of directors, a trusted peer group where you can discuss challenges you're having, get career advice, and just kind of gut check how you're thinking about your work, your career, and your life.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Offers a concrete career-development tactic practitioners can implement: forming a structured peer advisory group.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: With sidebar, senior leaders are matched with highly vetted, private, supportive peer groups to lean on for unbiased opinions, diverse perspectives, and raw feedback.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a mechanism for getting higher-quality feedback loops—useful for leadership growth and decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Why spend a decade finding your people when you can meet them at Sidebar today, jump the growing wait list of thousands of leaders from top tech companies by visiting sidebar.com/lenny to learn more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable, slightly contrarian push to accelerate network-building rather than relying on slow, organic connections.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: One of the most effective ways to create a big leap in your career and something that worked really well for me a few years ago is to create a personal board of directors, a trusted peer group where you can discuss challenges you're having, get career advice, and just kind of gut check how you're thinking about your work, your career, and your life.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Sidebar)
quotes.context: Introduces a practical career-growth framework—building a “personal board of directors” for ongoing advice and decision-quality checks.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With sidebar, senior leaders are matched with highly vetted, private, supportive peer groups to lean on for unbiased opinions, diverse perspectives, and raw feedback.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Sidebar)
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete mechanism for getting higher-quality feedback: vetted peers providing unbiased, diverse, and candid input.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You fell in love with building products for a reason, but sometimes the day-to-day reality is a little different than you imagined.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Jira Product Discovery)
quotes.context: Frames a common product-management gap between ideal work (strategy/customer focus) and operational reality.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With Jira product Discovery, you can gather all your product ideas and insights in one place and prioritize confidently.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Jira Product Discovery)
quotes.context: Actionable product ops guidance: centralize ideas/insights to enable more confident prioritization.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Great products are built by great teams, not just engineers, sales, support, leadership, even Greg from finance.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Jira Product Discovery)
quotes.context: Memorable reminder that product quality depends on cross-functional contribution, not a single function.

quotes.topic_title: Why vision matters and core elements
quotes.text: I think the first piece is that you absolutely need to have one, to start by saying that. Regardless of what level you are in the company. So people say, "Oh, I'm just a junior PM." Whatever level, there is some micro macro vision that you need to have.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: Actionable reminder that vision is required at every PM level, not just for senior leaders.

quotes.topic_title: Why vision matters and core elements
quotes.text: Because essentially if you got on a plane and the pilot was like, "I don't really know where we're going, but I'm a really good pilot. The company needs to fly 400 flights this year. So I'm trying to make that happen, but trust me, we'll get there. There might be turbulence, I'm not sure." You probably would be thinking twice about staying on that flight, right?
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: Memorable analogy showing why execution skill without a clear destination (vision) fails to inspire confidence or alignment.

quotes.topic_title: Why vision matters and core elements
quotes.text: And that's the vision not to be confused with the mission, which is we want to fly people where they're going safe. That's not... It's like a picture.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: Clarifies a practical distinction: vision is a vivid destination image, while mission is the ongoing purpose.

quotes.topic_title: Why vision matters and core elements
quotes.text: The first one is it needs to be lofty. So it needs to be something that feels... It almost scares you in an exciting way, right? Like, oh, my God, this is something I can get up every morning. And if we did that, goddamn. But at the same time, it needs to be realistic and attainable, so it cannot feel so pie in the sky that it feels so out of reach, right?
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: Gives a usable bar for calibrating vision: emotionally energizing yet still believable and reachable.

quotes.topic_title: Why vision matters and core elements
quotes.text: So four things. So it has to be lofty, it has to be realistic, it has to be devoid of any tech or limitations of today, and it has to be grounded in a very clear and potent problem. User problem.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: A concise checklist practitioners can apply to evaluate or craft a product vision.

quotes.topic_title: Examples of strong visions (Uber, Tesla, Mars)
quotes.text: So that's the mission. That doesn't really tell me what the image looks like when I get there, but that's like when I wake up every day, I'm like, "Why do I work in this company?" It's that make transportation reliable everywhere for everyone.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: Clarifies a practical mission-vs-vision distinction: mission motivates daily purpose but doesn’t paint the end-state picture.

quotes.topic_title: Examples of strong visions (Uber, Tesla, Mars)
quotes.text: The vision was a world where you get to this continuous trip so that you do not need parking. Because cities, 25% of the average city is parking spaces.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: A concrete, visualizable vision anchored by a striking data point that makes the opportunity feel real and urgent.

quotes.topic_title: Examples of strong visions (Uber, Tesla, Mars)
quotes.text: So it's not crazy. It's attainable.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: A useful bar for strong visions: ambitious enough to inspire, but grounded enough to be believable and actionable.

quotes.topic_title: Examples of strong visions (Uber, Tesla, Mars)
quotes.text: I think one that's lofty and I dance between whether it's attainable or not, is Elon Musk saying, "We're going to get to Mars." He believes it. He believes it so much that sometimes I'm like, "I guess, we're going to Mars."
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: Highlights how conviction can shift perceived feasibility—an example of the “lofty vs attainable” tension in vision-setting.

quotes.topic_title: Examples of strong visions (Uber, Tesla, Mars)
quotes.text: So yeah, I mean, the beautiful things about visions is that it helps you decide it. Is that a work... Do I care about this problem? Is it something I want to do? And then you can take it or leave it.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: Frames vision as a decision filter for commitment and fit—useful for teams and individuals evaluating what to work on.

quotes.topic_title: Mission vs vision: practical distinction
quotes.text: The vision would be once we're up there, me describing the picture of what we're going to see, we're going to get there, we're going to look around, we'll be the Himalayas, be beautiful, we'll be above the clouds, probably out of breath. That's the vision.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: A vivid mental model: vision is a concrete, sensory description of the future state as if you’ve already arrived.

quotes.topic_title: Mission vs vision: practical distinction
quotes.text: So that's the vision and then the mission is the purpose of why we're doing that.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: A crisp, actionable distinction practitioners can use to separate “future state” (vision) from “why we exist” (mission).

quotes.topic_title: Mission vs vision: practical distinction
quotes.text: And then the mission is the purpose and some set of guiding principles as to what will allow you to achieve that vision.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: Adds a practical layer: mission isn’t just purpose—it includes guiding principles that shape how you execute toward the vision.

quotes.topic_title: Mission vs vision: practical distinction
quotes.text: The mission is essentially the why and why you exist and the purpose for your team slash company and the vision... The word vision almost tells you what it is. It's what it looks like when you get there.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable shorthand teams can adopt to align quickly: mission = why; vision = what “arrival” looks like.

quotes.topic_title: Mission vs vision: practical distinction
quotes.text: Maybe this is my Uber, but you can see a computer on every desk. That's what I mean by it has to be realistic.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: A counterbalance to overly aspirational vision statements: the vision should be imaginable and grounded enough to feel real.

quotes.topic_title: Vision artifacts: story frameworks and narratives
quotes.text: one of the most powerful skills of a product manager is storytelling, right? Because you look at generation after generation after generation, what people pass on as stories, they're not numbers, they're not stats, it's stories.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: Highlights storytelling as a core PM skill and explains why stories outlast metrics in how humans remember and transmit meaning.

quotes.topic_title: Vision artifacts: story frameworks and narratives
quotes.text: And actually when you blend stories with numbers, so if you do numbers alone or numbers with stories or stories alone, the gap is so wide in stories alone. So it's not metrics blended with stories. It's a story, just a pure story.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: A counterintuitive take that vision artifacts should prioritize narrative over metrics to be memorable and motivating.

quotes.topic_title: Vision artifacts: story frameworks and narratives
quotes.text: And it's once upon a time, write the problem and then write something and then write something, and then one day something happened. And as a result, the state of the world where we're trying to be.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: Provides a simple, reusable narrative template teams can plug into to express a vision as a story.

quotes.topic_title: Vision artifacts: story frameworks and narratives
quotes.text: So I go to the future and I write the headline I would see. And I write the subtitle, just that, and I'll actually use the... I'll [inaudible 00:18:01] it into the page of TechCrunch or [inaudible 00:18:04] or something just so it looks realistic.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: A practical “working backwards” method: make the vision concrete by drafting a future headline/subtitle as if the product already succeeded.

quotes.topic_title: Vision artifacts: story frameworks and narratives
quotes.text: that image got people so excited about, oh, it's possible. I can see that.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: Shows the persuasive power of a simple visual vision artifact to create belief and alignment across stakeholders.

quotes.topic_title: Working backwards: headlines, articles, and screenshots
quotes.text: So you'll hear me say product management is clarity and conviction.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: A concise mental model for what great PM work optimizes for, setting up why working-backwards artifacts create focus.

quotes.topic_title: Working backwards: headlines, articles, and screenshots
quotes.text: And in writing the headline, you have to focus. Headline is not like... It's not a PRD, right? It's a headline.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to use a headline as a forcing function for prioritization and crisp articulation of impact.

quotes.topic_title: Working backwards: headlines, articles, and screenshots
quotes.text: So I took the Google Play Store and then I created rounded rectangles, just blank rectangles, four panels. And then I printed that out and I gave everyone a sheet and I said, "If we solve these problems, we solve all these problems that we've identified, what would be the screenshots?"
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable workshop technique to align teams on the “few big rocks” by visualizing app-store screenshots.

quotes.topic_title: Working backwards: headlines, articles, and screenshots
quotes.text: The thing though is I feel like it's an easy cop out to be like, "Oh, but my design team doesn't have resources." So I'm like, "No, that's not an excuse. Start drawing it with your hands in the app store."
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: Countering a common blocker with a low-fidelity alternative that keeps momentum and narrative clarity.

quotes.topic_title: Working backwards: headlines, articles, and screenshots
quotes.text: I wrote a headline of Uber really wants to replace your... I put it as your clipper card in San Francisco. Because I wanted my San Francisco buddies to relate to what I was saying. So I was like, "Uber is now replacing your Clipper card. All you need is your phone and the app."
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: A specific example of tailoring a working-backwards headline to a relatable analog to provoke feedback and drive alignment.

quotes.topic_title: No-designer excuse and low-fidelity visualization
quotes.text: The thing though is I feel like it's an easy cop out to be like, "Oh, but my design team doesn't have resources." So I'm like, "No, that's not an excuse. Start drawing it with your hands in the app store."
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: Pushes PMs to take ownership of vision storytelling by creating rough visuals themselves instead of waiting on design bandwidth.

quotes.topic_title: No-designer excuse and low-fidelity visualization
quotes.text: I'm obsessed with Steve Jobs. He would say, "Tell the story without slides." Right? So that mocking it up is just so you can actually bring that narrative and tell that story.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: A mental model that prioritizes narrative clarity over polished artifacts, using mocks only to support the story.

quotes.topic_title: No-designer excuse and low-fidelity visualization
quotes.text: And do an app store or sketch it out or use little rectangles to show low fidelity mocks. Do not use, I don't have a designer, to be the excuse for why you don't bring it to life.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: Gives concrete, low-effort tactics for visualizing a product vision without a designer.

quotes.topic_title: No-designer excuse and low-fidelity visualization
quotes.text: I sketched this thing once and I gave it to a designer. It was literally post-it notes and they were like, "Okay, I see where you're going and it's exciting. I have some cycles, I'll spin it up."
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: A specific example showing how even crude artifacts can unlock designer engagement and resourcing once the narrative is compelling.

quotes.topic_title: Developing vision: empathize, create, evangelize
quotes.text: Yeah. There are three pieces if you think about it. So one is what I call empathize. The second is create. So we spend a lot of time talking about create, the middle piece. Another's evangelize.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: Introduces a simple, repeatable three-part framework for developing product vision end-to-end.

quotes.topic_title: Developing vision: empathize, create, evangelize
quotes.text: Then the create piece where it's okay, now we've solved this problem. What does the world look like? That's the vision we've just been talking about. And then finally, evangelize.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: Defines vision as a concrete future-state after the problem is solved, and emphasizes the need to sell it over time.

quotes.topic_title: Developing vision: empathize, create, evangelize
quotes.text: So I set out a vision, for example at YouTube last year that was called Vision 2026. And only this year, a year and a half later, are we now at a stage where it's actually going into the planning cycle.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: Provides a real example showing that vision-setting can have a long lag before it translates into planning and funding.

quotes.topic_title: Developing vision: empathize, create, evangelize
quotes.text: There's always going to be those people which is why I said you need to come up with a vision that's in a vacuum of the technical limitations because the limitations of today might not be the limitations of tomorrow.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder to avoid anchoring vision on current technical constraints, since they can change.

quotes.topic_title: Developing vision: empathize, create, evangelize
quotes.text: Dog food, meaning using your own product, absolutely a must. Cat food using your competitors or other people in the landscape's products.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: Offers a memorable, actionable practice for empathy: use your product and systematically use competitors’ products too.

quotes.topic_title: Empathize tactics: dogfooding, competitor use, intuition
quotes.text: You need to do understand work.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: A memorable framing that pushes PMs to actively build empathy through hands-on product understanding, not just abstract planning.

quotes.topic_title: Empathize tactics: dogfooding, competitor use, intuition
quotes.text: empathize comes very easily if you dog food and then cat food. Dog food, meaning using your own product, absolutely a must. Cat food using your competitors or other people in the landscape's products.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: A practical, repeatable empathy tactic: systematically use your own product and competitors to surface issues and opportunities.

quotes.topic_title: Empathize tactics: dogfooding, competitor use, intuition
quotes.text: And so I find too many people lean into and, "Let's go test it, let's go do some research." It's like, dude, you're a human. Look at the products. Would you use that? You built some intuition from just exposing yourself to really good products.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that research shouldn’t replace product judgment—PMs should cultivate intuition by studying great experiences.

quotes.topic_title: Empathize tactics: dogfooding, competitor use, intuition
quotes.text: the tactical thing that I almost make every PM on my team do I call it top 10 things you should know. It's a living document.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: A concrete operating mechanism for teams: maintain a shared, continuously updated list of the most important known problems.

quotes.topic_title: Top 10 problems doc and stakeholder inputs
quotes.text: So that living document means that for me, if I go around at least my minus one, not just for me but my engineering partner's minus ones, and my design partner's minus ones, and we chat them and say, "What are the top five problems for studio?" They should all have the same answer. This says I've done my job because then we all know the problems.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: A concrete alignment test for whether a team truly shares a common understanding of the most important problems.

quotes.topic_title: Top 10 problems doc and stakeholder inputs
quotes.text: So that's the empathize bit. I'm spending a lot of time on this because I can't tell you how many times the clarity of the problem, going back to clarity and conviction, is missing and that problem is kind of like the North star. Everything's going on, but there's a north star that doesn't move.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: Reframes problem clarity as the stable “North star” that anchors strategy and execution amid constant activity.

quotes.topic_title: Top 10 problems doc and stakeholder inputs
quotes.text: If I could put all the research into Bard or ChatGPT and it could spit out a PRD, then you haven't done your job.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: A provocative bar for PM value: synthesis and judgment beyond what AI can generate from existing inputs.

quotes.topic_title: Top 10 problems doc and stakeholder inputs
quotes.text: I'll sometimes bring them in at the beginning of the strategy session and give them a template, 10 things you should know. So you use my framework to give me 10 problems. Because if you say, "Come present," they'll do like 50 slides. No, that's just 10 things you should know and stack rank them.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: A practical stakeholder-input mechanism that forces prioritization and comparability across functions.

quotes.topic_title: Top 10 problems doc and stakeholder inputs
quotes.text: One of them was like the average reading age of an American is 11 years old.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: A specific data point that can directly reshape product decisions (e.g., simplifying language, using visuals).

quotes.topic_title: Strategy sessions: insights, strategy, big rocks
quotes.text: I usually have strategy sessions of three days. I've tried to do it in two days. That is the absolute limit because I think you need to create white space for just the magic to happen.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: A practical recommendation on strategy-offsite duration, emphasizing the importance of leaving enough time for synthesis.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy sessions: insights, strategy, big rocks
quotes.text: But I usually use a framework that it's literally what I call the narrative structure. So when we get into the conviction part, the clarity is the problems to solve. The conviction is the narrative. The framing of that conviction is insights, strategy, big rocks.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: A memorable framework for structuring strategy work into a narrative that moves from problems to a prioritized plan.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy sessions: insights, strategy, big rocks
quotes.text: So the insights day is just focused on understand work, these five problems, actually using the app, doing teardowns of other apps. It's just like a day of understanding.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: Concrete guidance for what to do on day one: immerse in the product and competitive teardowns before jumping to solutions.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy sessions: insights, strategy, big rocks
quotes.text: And then the second day is where we now go into the strategy of all the problems we've seen, the 10, which are the ones we want to focus on in which order?
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: A clear prioritization method: enumerate problems, pick the few to focus on, and explicitly sequence them.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy sessions: insights, strategy, big rocks
quotes.text: But you hit on the fantastic point which I was going to connect later, which is when you get to the evangelized stage, humans love to know you heard them.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: A stakeholder-management insight: involving people early makes later evangelism and buy-in dramatically easier.

quotes.topic_title: Evangelizing vision: team, stakeholders, leadership
quotes.text: In terms of evangelizing, I think about three concentric circles.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: Introduces a simple rollout framework for spreading a product vision from closest collaborators outward.

quotes.topic_title: Evangelizing vision: team, stakeholders, leadership
quotes.text: And that will be a living document, comments, open for comments, no edit, not view only, comments because you want anyone to leave comments in there and just feel they have a say.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: Gives a concrete, repeatable tactic for creating buy-in and surfacing feedback without losing document control.

quotes.topic_title: Evangelizing vision: team, stakeholders, leadership
quotes.text: You don't have to respond to all of them. You don't have to resolve all of them, but just if you put rocks in a washing machine, they polish each other. I like this friction.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: Reframes feedback friction as a useful mechanism to improve the vision rather than something to eliminate.

quotes.topic_title: Evangelizing vision: team, stakeholders, leadership
quotes.text: So go as big as possible. Go big. Let people tell you to pull back. Let your manager use lasso and pull you back. Go as much as possible.
quotes.speaker: Ebi Atawodi
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to start with an expansive vision and rely on leadership to constrain it, instead of self-censoring early.
